chapter.title: Scope
chapter.para: This document defines how WebRTC and related protocols are to be used for ONVIF clients and devices to establish a peer-to-peer connection between a client and a device using a signaling server.

chapter.title: Normative references
chapter.para: W3C WebRTC Specification: Real-Time Communication Between Browsers
IETF RFC 8829 - JavaScript Session Establishment Protocol (JSEP)
IETF RFC 8866 - SDP: Session Description Protocol
IETF RFC 8489 - Session Traversal Utilities for NAT (STUN)
IETF RFC 8656 - Traversal Using Relays around NAT (TURN)

entry.para: A server that manages the WebRTC connections between clients and devices.

chapter.title: Overview
chapter.para: This specification contains documentation and examples of the signaling protocol used to set up a WebRTC peer-to-peer connection. The setup involves three participants: client, device and signaling server.

In this figure,
The client represents a real user who initiates the WebRTC session.
The device is the resource delivering the media, for example a camera.
The signaling server is the mediator that both client and device connect to in order to establish a peer-to-peer connection between them.

The Signaling Protocol described in this specification details the data exchange between client and device via the signaling server as examples. The formal API is defined in separate JSON schema files.
Once a peer-to-peer connection has been established how WebRTC is used is described in the WebRTC usage chapter.

chapter.title: Signaling Protocol
chapter.para: The Signaling Protocol defines the messages between a client and a device in a WebRTC system. The messages are always sent via the signaling server called server from now on.

section.title: Connecting to the signaling server
section.para: A client first needs to connect to the server, by setting up a websocket to, for example, the URL:

where signaling.companyname.com should be replaced with the server's address, and access_token should be replaced with a valid access token that the server will accept. See for how to get an access token.
The signaling messages are then sent as JSON text messages in the websocket.

Directly after connecting a websocket to the server the client typically gets a hello message from the server, with the client's assigned signaling id. Note that this ID is not directly used in the Signaling Protocol.

section.title: Message structure
section.para: The messages shown in this chapter are sent as JSON text messages over the websocket connection. Generally a message contains two parts; the first part is processed by the server and the second part is intended for the device. So in essence device bound messages and responses are encapsulated in the data field of the first part.

note.para: Note that messages sent via the server may be delivered out-of-order; for optimal scalability messages should be handled asynchronously.

section.para: Below are explanations for some of the key/value pairs that are seen repeatedly.

entry.para: The ID of the intended device, or the device that sent the message. See for how to get available IDs.
The related organization's ID. See for how to get available IDs.
Client's access token that allows signaling. See for how to get an access token.
Optional value that may be useful for logging and debugging

section.title: Device level keys inside data blocks

entry.para: Value chosen by client to identify the p2p session, so that different sessions can exist between the same client and device
Optional value that, if present in a request, should be included in the corresponding response

section.title: Param level keys inside params blocks

entry.para: Media profile. See for how to get available profiles.

section.title: Initializing a new WebRTC session
section.para: A new WebRTC session is initiated by the client requesting the device to produce an SDP offer using a initSession message.

section.title: Live session
section.para: Use an initSession message of type live to request a live video and/or audio session.
The server then responds with a copy of the initSession message, including details for the STUN and TURN servers that can be used:

section.title: SDP and ICE candidate negotiation
section.para: Once a P2P signaling channel has been set up using the initSession message the next step is to exchange SDP and ICE candidates. The dynamics and the format of the SDP and ICE candidate strings are defined in RFC 8829.

section.para: An SDP offer is always sent from the device to the client. Note that the contents of params map directly to the contents of the RTCSessionDescription interface described in the W3C WebRTC Specification.

section.para: Both client and device produce ICE candidates and send them to each other using a addIceCandidate message.

section.title: Error handling
section.para: Errors that can be immediately reported when receiving a request are reported directly in its corresponding response. However, errors may also occur later during the subsequent session setup or after it has been setup and is running. These types of errors are reported in an event message. Both 'events' and 'responses' include a numeric error code, and a human-readable message.

entry.para: Media streaming failed, audio from client to device
Media streaming failed, connection to upstream source lost

section.para: When errors are reported by the client or device the error message is encapsulated in a signaling message. The server may itself send errors by using its own error type message.

section.title: Reconnecting
section.para: If a client is disconnected it's up to the client to reconnect again using the same procedure as was used initially, i.e. start from scratch. Each client should use an individual ascending interval strategy to avoid that all clients reconnect at the same time.

chapter.title: WebRTC Usage
chapter.para: This chapter describes ONVIF specific usage of WebRTC regarding how to send data between the client and device on the peer-to-peer connection.

Devices MAY define profiles for different streaming scenarios that can be choosen by the client based on the available bandwidth or other limiting factors. For example, a specific profile for mobile clients, another one for high quality streaming, etc.

section.title: Video
section.para: When using WebRTC with a web browser only certain codecs will work. Because of this ONVIF recommends to use the h.264 codec.

section.title: Audio
section.para: When using WebRTC with a web browser only certain codecs will work. Because of this ONVIF recommends to use the Opus or PCMU codec.

section.title: Metadata
section.para: A device could send event and analytics metadata on a WebRTC datachannel. This is not covered in the this version of this specifcation but may be added in future versions.

section.title: Commands
section.para: A client could send PTZ and other commands on a WebRTC datachannel. This is not covered in the this version of this specifcation but may be added in future versions.

chapter.title: Directory Protocol
chapter.para: The Directory Protocol is used to query organizations, devices and profiles in a directory.

section.title: Listing organizations
section.para: List organizations that are accessible by the user.

section.title: Listing devices
section.para: List devices that are accessible by the user.

section.title: Listing profiles
section.para: List streaming profiles together with video and audio settings.

chapter.title: Login Protocol
chapter.para: The Login Protocol is used to authenticate the user and get access to services.
